Expectation1: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation1: A school zone with children near the curb appears just as a construction detour narrows the lanes
Expectation2: Organize and lead religious education classes for children and adults
Situation2: The regular weekly religious education class for the parish's children is scheduled.
Story: I gripped the steering wheel, my taxi crawling through the school zone. Children clustered near the curb, their laughter rising above the hum of engines. The construction detour had squeezed the lanes, and traffic was barely moving. I glanced at the dashboard clock—fifteen minutes until the religious education class I was supposed to lead at the parish. As a priest, I knew the parents and children counted on me to be there, to guide them, to keep the rhythm of their faith steady. But as a taxi driver, I was bound by the law, by the responsibility to keep these children safe, to drive slowly and carefully, no matter how late I was running. My phone buzzed with a message from the parish secretary: “Are you on your way?” My heart pounded. I could see the expectant faces of the children waiting for me at the church, but I couldn’t ignore the vulnerable children just outside my window. The weight of both roles pressed down on me, each demanding something I couldn’t give to the other.
